chapters.title: # Objectives
chapters.contentMd: # Objectives This lab introduces our Case Study CoffeeMate with a look at some of the basic features we can implement in an Android App. In this Lab, you will be required to develop the first version of our Case Study, CoffeeMate.1.0. We'll build on this project over the coming weeks & months. On completion of this lab you'll be able to - add multiple activities & associated layouts to an Android project - switch between 'screens' - display a simple dialog window - display and add functionality to a custom menu

chapters.title: # Project Setup-
chapters.contentMd: # Project Setup- "CoffeeMate.1.0" ![Figure 1: Start a new Android Studio project](img/firstrun.png) Press "Next" (or click the option) and then select your Activity type, for this app we'll choose a **Basic Activity**. ![Figure 2: Choose Your Project](img/new01.png) Select the Platform you want your app to run on - we'll just stick with Phone & Tablet here ![Figure 3: Configure Your Project](img/new02.png) Change default project name to **CoffeeMate.1.0**, change the default package name to **ie.cm** (or provide a company domain) and select a project location and language (here, Java). Select an appropriate Minimum SDK (API 28 in the screenshot) After you press "Finish", you should now have something similar to the following: ![Figure 4: Project open in Layout View](img/new03.png) and ![Figure 5: Project open in Design View](img/new04.png) If you don't see both layouts you can switch to 'Design + Blueprint' View Next, as an exercise, select File->Close Project, to close the project so we can import it again. Once the project is open again, familiarise yourself with the project layout ![Figure 5: Project Structure](img/project.png) the initial xml layouts or "screens" are first displayed, this is one of the many resources you will be using and creating throughout this module. We will experiment later with modifying this layout, but first you should run the application. Select the Project (**CoffeeMate.1.0**) and then select the 'Play' button. If you haven't done so already, you will be asked to select/create an AVD (Android Virtual Device), as in the previous lab. The Virtual Device is very heavy on resources so you may need to choose settings below what is selected in the Screenshots. Otherwise, use the settings as above and your first Android App should launch, (Once you've unlocked the device!):

chapters.title: # Starter Resources & Refactor
chapters.contentMd: # Starter Resources & Refactor Before we begin, we should rename some of our initial resources and files to allow us to manage our project as we add more Activities and resources in later versions of the app. so first, - rename your **MainActivity.java** to **Home.java** - rename your **activity_main.xml** to **home.xml** & your **content_main.xml** to **content_home** respectively and - rename your **menu_main.xml** file to **menu_home.xml** You should end up with a project like this ![Figure 6: Updated Project Structure](img/project1.png) and you rename files like so ![Figure 7: Refactor->Rename Files & resources](img/refactor.png) Just Right-Mouse-Click on the selected file and choose Refactor->Rename. Also, to make things a bit easier, you can download some starter resources for this lab here - [Resources](archives/drawable.zip). It contains all of drawable (image) resources you'll need to complete this lab. So replace your existing drawable folder with this one once you've extracted the archive somewhere on your hard disk. Once you have the drawable folder 'updated' there's a few other resources to update, so first of all, replace your colors.xml with the following: ~~~xml #4893e4 #346daf #2460a6 #ffffff #f7f7f7 #000000 ~~~ Replace your strings.xml with ~~~xml CoffeeMate.1.0 This is the help screen for CoffeeMate Basically\, if you need help on using this app, you probably shouldn\'t be using it CoffeeMate 1.0 CoffeeMate provides the user with a quick and easy way to manage a list of coffees and your favourite coffees. chapters.title: # Our Custom Menu
# The Help Screen
chapters.contentMd: # The Help Screen To implement the Help feature of our App you need to : - create a new Activity (Help.java) and associated layout. - link this activity with our menu. So, using Android Studio, go to File->New->Activity and again create a new Empty Activity in the ie.cm.activities package. ![](img/newhelp.png) Next, extend your Help.java Activity from "Base" as the parent class. This will insure we have the same menu as the other activities. Mainly for practice, design your Help screen something like the following, but you can design it whatever way you want really, so take some time to customise this layout to your own liking. ![](img/starterapphelp.png) Once you're happy with your own Help Screen, go ahead and wire it up to your menuHelp method in your Base class, so when the user selects the 'Help' option from the menu, they are taken to your help screen (very like what you did for the info dialog). Now we can move on to actually adding a Coffee to our App.
